dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Zuckerberg's new policy on political advertising is a complete 180, isn't it? He's now pushing to eliminate all of it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Zuckerberg's new policy on political advertising is a complete one hundred eighty, isn't it? He's now pushing to eliminate all of it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Twitter announced on Wednesday its intent to abolish political advertising on its platform, saying that political message reach should be earned, not bought. The announcement from Dorseys Twitter account came on the cusp of Facebooks scheduled third-quarter earnings call and after a month of relentless campaigning from Zuckerberg on the issue of political advertising and free speech.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and he's such a staunch proponent of online censorship now—it's wild how much his stance has shifted from the early days.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and he's such a staunch proponent of online censorship now-it's wild how much his stance has shifted from the early days.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Zuckerberg has positioned Facebook as an American-values-based company that champions free speech by allowing anyone to publish any of their thoughts, as long as they dont threaten physical harm. I dont think most people want to live in a world where you can only post things that tech companies judge to be 100% true, Zuckerberg said during a Georgetown University speech earlier this month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then you've got Dorsey over at Twitter, uh, applauding this move? Which is ironic because his platform bans politicians from making false claims in ads.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then you've got Dorsey over at Twitter, uh, applauding this move? Which is ironic because his platform bans politicians from making false claims in ads.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Twitter announced on Wednesday its intent to abolish political advertising on its platform, saying that political message reach should be earned, not bought. Dorseys comments took aim at how Zuckerberg has defended Facebooks political ads policy, which allows politicians and political candidates to make false claims in advertisements.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, Dorsey's all about free speech as long as it doesn't promote hate or violence—but he seems to think Zuckerberg's new direction is a win?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, Dorsey's all about free speech as long as it doesn't promote hate or violence-but he seems to think Zuckerberg's new direction is a win?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: During an appearance at the Twitter News Summit in New York City after Zuckerbergs Georgetown speech, Dorsey said that Zuckerbergs free speech argument had a major gap and flaw in the substance he was getting across. There's some amount of revisionist history in all his storytelling, Dorsey said of Zuckerberg.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's so confusing! Like, Zuckerberg says this is about "free expression," but then he talks about restricting political messaging based on opinion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's so confusing! Like, Zuckerberg says this is about free expression, but then he talks about restricting political messaging based on opinion.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Zuckerberg has positioned Facebook as an American-values-based company that champions free speech by allowing anyone to publish any of their thoughts, as long as they dont threaten physical harm. I dont think most people want to live in a world where you can only post things that tech companies judge to be 100% true, Zuckerberg said during a Georgetown University speech earlier this month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And that fist bump emoji he added? I mean, come on. It feels like they're teaming up publicly because of the pressure around the 2020 election.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And that fist bump emoji he added? I mean, come on. It feels like they're teaming up publicly because of the pressure around the twenty twenty election.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then Dorsey totally mocks Facebook in that leaked audio from October 1st—saying Facebook can't invest in safety like Twitter does.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then Dorsey totally mocks Facebook in that leaked audio from October first-saying Facebook can't invest in safety like Twitter does.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On October 1, when The Verge published leaked audio from a Facebook company meeting, Zuckerberg mocks Twitter and its efforts to fix the health of their network. Its why Twitter cant do as good of a job as we can, Zuckerberg said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that Wall Street Journal leak! He claimed Twitter's safety investment is smaller than Facebook's entire revenue. That's a pretty direct shot.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that Wall Street Journal leak! He claimed Twitter's safety investment is smaller than Facebook's entire revenue. That's a pretty direct shot.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On October 1, when The Verge published leaked audio from a Facebook company meeting, Zuckerberg mocks Twitter and its efforts to fix the health of their network. Our investment on safety is bigger than the whole revenue of their company.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And yet at the Facebook Town Hall, Zuckerberg called Dorsey's free speech argument flawed, with a "major gap."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And yet at the Facebook Town Hall, Zuckerberg called Dorsey's free speech argument flawed, with a major gap.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: During an appearance at the Twitter News Summit in New York City after Zuckerbergs Georgetown speech, Dorsey said that Zuckerbergs free speech argument had a major gap and flaw in the substance he was getting across.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's like, this weird public alliance but with constant jabs. Do they actually agree or are they just performing for regulators?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like, this weird public alliance but with constant jabs. Do they actually agree or are they just performing for regulators?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then Dorsey saying he'd "absolutely" join the Libra project? After all that? The collaboration is all over the place.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then Dorsey saying he'd absolutely join the Libra project? After all that? The collaboration is all over the place.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When asked if he would join Facebooks Libra project, Dorsey had a simple answer: Hell, no.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, it feels like they're both trying to position themselves as the good guys before the election, but their strategies are totally opposite.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, it feels like they're both trying to position themselves as the good guys before the election, but their strategies are totally opposite.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, one's restricting ads, the other allows them but fact-checks... but they're both facing the same disinformation pressures.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, one's restricting ads, the other allows them but fact-checks... but they're both facing the same disinformation pressures.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dorseys comments took aim at how Zuckerberg has defended Facebooks political ads policy, which allows politicians and political candidates to make false claims in advertisements.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. It's a messy, messy PR battle disguised as a principled stand.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. It's a messy, messy P R battle disguised as a principled stand.

artist_script:
HostA: Zuckerberg's new policy on political advertising is a complete 180, isn't it? He's now pushing to eliminate all of it.
HostB: Yeah, and he's such a staunch proponent of online censorship now—it's wild how much his stance has shifted from the early days.
HostA: And then you've got Dorsey over at Twitter, uh, applauding this move? Which is ironic because his platform bans politicians from making false claims in ads.
HostB: Right, Dorsey's all about free speech as long as it doesn't promote hate or violence—but he seems to think Zuckerberg's new direction is a win?
HostA: It's so confusing! Like, Zuckerberg says this is about "free expression," but then he talks about restricting political messaging based on opinion.
HostB: And that fist bump emoji he added? I mean, come on. It feels like they're teaming up publicly because of the pressure around the 2020 election.
HostA: But then Dorsey totally mocks Facebook in that leaked audio from October 1st—saying Facebook can't invest in safety like Twitter does.
HostB: Oh, that Wall Street Journal leak! He claimed Twitter's safety investment is smaller than Facebook's entire revenue. That's a pretty direct shot.
HostA: And yet at the Facebook Town Hall, Zuckerberg called Dorsey's free speech argument flawed, with a "major gap."
HostB: It's like, this weird public alliance but with constant jabs. Do they actually agree or are they just performing for regulators?
HostA: And then Dorsey saying he'd "absolutely" join the Libra project? After all that? The collaboration is all over the place.
HostB: Honestly, it feels like they're both trying to position themselves as the good guys before the election, but their strategies are totally opposite.
HostA: Yeah, one's restricting ads, the other allows them but fact-checks... but they're both facing the same disinformation pressures.
HostB: Exactly. It's a messy, messy PR battle disguised as a principled stand.
